The Mime Union Leader Opens a Detective Agency

The city was quiet enough to hear the paperwork breathe. So was the founder, a mime union leader with enough seniority to freeze an entire picket line mid-glance. She opened her office on the thirteenth floor of a building with no elevators, because gravity here is optional and the stairs were mostly a vibe. Her union card now doubled as a private investigator badge, embossed in ink that glinted like a warning.

OPERATIONS
FULL MOON ONLY
NO SPEAKING
Gravity
Optional

Beginning: The Case of the Missing Gravity Clause

The mime union’s charter had always included a small line about gravity being “negotiable,” but someone had crossed it out with a red pen and a sigh. That meant the building’s lawyers were suddenly walking instead of gliding, and morale was trapped between two floors like a bored elevator.

She took the case in the usual way: by placing her hand on an invisible wall and waiting for the city to notice. The city did. A courier delivered a dossier written entirely in impeccable silence and stapled with the kind of staple that looked like it would hold together a solar system.

“You’re the only investigator who can interrogate a suspect without letting the rumor leak,” said the Commissioner, through a translator holding a whiteboard. “You also have the union votes. We need both.”

She nodded. The narrative shifted. A full moon rose like a spotlight in rehearsal, reminding her that the agency’s operating hours were a legal agreement and also a dramatic choice.

Agency Rule 1: Every case begins with a bow, ends with a receipt, and pauses when the moon is anything less than theatrical.
File 01 — The gravity clause wasn’t stolen. It walked away during negotiations, wearing a trench coat borrowed from an accountant. The coat is still missing.
Translator’s Note — The mime asked no questions, yet everyone confessed. There is a procedural loop here: in silence, the truth is too loud to ignore.
Investigation progress

Middle: Letters, Testimonials, and a Hovered Secret

Letter

From the Curtain Guild

“She asked for the stage directions and held them like they were a newborn. When gravity vanished, she didn’t panic. She pinned it to the wall and labeled it ‘Maybe.’”

Testimonial

From a Former Suspect

“I tried to flee upward. She caught me with an invisible lasso and a polite eyebrow. I have not stolen anything since. I cannot even steal attention now.”

Hover

The Secret Memo

“The red pen belonged to the Treasurer. He marked the gravity clause as ‘optional’ because he wanted to save on stair maintenance. He did not account for dramatic exits.”

Outside, the full moon hung like a union vote: decisive, cold, and impossible to ignore. The mime leader checked her pocket watch — it had no hands, only a tiny stage and a spotlight that flicked on at midnight.

“If gravity is optional,” she signed in air, “then so is guilt.”

End: The Night the Agency Floated Open

At the appointed hour, the agency opened. The door sighed like a velvet curtain. Gravity left the room without filing a grievance. The mime stepped into the corridor and conducted the building like an orchestra, each tenant drifting into their own confession. By dawn, the clause returned, embarrassed but intact.

The Treasurer signed a memorandum agreeing to never negotiate with lunar events again. The union ratified the agency’s founding charter: full moons only, silence always, and investigations conducted with the dignity of someone who can trap a lie inside an invisible box.

Closing Argument: In a world where gravity is optional, accountability is the only weight that matters. The mime lifted it with one hand.

Postscript: The Agency Ledger

The ledger is kept in a minimalist lockbox that floats when it wants to. Each case is recorded in ink the color of a siren. The last entry reads: “Full moon tomorrow.” But the calendar is smudged, so the agency keeps its door on a chain and its lights ready. If you want to hire them, bring a flashlight and the courage to sit in a chair that may or may not be under you.

This is a full-moon establishment, but it prefers the drama of uncertainty.
